context: <a0_0>Antarctica<a0_0/> is the coldest of Earth's continents. The coldest natural temperature ever recorded on Earth was <a1_0><b5_0><b8_0>−89.2 °C<b5_0/><a1_0/> (−128.6 °F)<b8_0/> at the Soviet (now Russian) Vostok Station in Antarctica on <a2_0>21 July 1983<a2_0/>. For comparison, this is 10.7 °C (20 °F) colder than subliming dry ice at one atmosphere of partial pressure, but since CO2 only makes up 0.039% of <b9_0>air,<b9_0/> temperatures of less than −150 °C (−238 °F) would be needed to produce <b10_0>dry ice snow<b10_0/> in Antarctica. Antarctica is a <a3_0>frozen desert<a3_0/> with little precipitation; the <b6_0><b11_0>South Pole<b11_0/><b6_0/> itself receives less than 10 cm (4 in) per year, on average. Temperatures reach a minimum of between −80 °C (−112 °F) and −89.2 °C (−128.6 °F) in the interior in winter and reach a maximum of between 5 °C (41 °F) and 15 °C (59 °F) near the coast in summer. <a4_0>Sunburn<a4_0/> is often a health issue as the <b7_0>snow<b7_0/> surface reflects almost all of the ultraviolet light falling on it. Given the latitude, long periods of constant darkness or constant sunlight create climates unfamiliar to human beings in much of the rest of the world.
